awd_titl_txt: Experimental Studies of the Properties of the QGP and the QCD Phase Diagram
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is the theoretical framework that describes the strong nuclear force. The fundamental particles that interact via this force are the quarks and gluons that build up protons and neutrons, which in turn build up the atomic nuclei at the cores of all atoms. This project aims to study the nature of matter at the very high temperatures reached in relativistic heavy ion collisions.  The group will study how protons and neutrons melt into constituent quarks and gluons, which are no longer bound under these conditions. This high-temperature phase of nuclear matter is called the Quark-Gluon Plasma (QGP). Heavy-ion experiments at the Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider and the Large Hadron Collider have produced striking evidence for QGP formation. The field is moving towards a quantitative understanding of the thermodynamic properties of the QGP, and this work will contribute to that understanding. 

This project focuses on the experimental measurement of two distinct thermodynamic properties of this novel state of nuclear matter with the STAR and the CMS experiments. The first property to be measured is the temperature produced in the hottest stages of the collision. This is done via the study of Upsilon mesons, a bound state of heavy "bottom" quarks. In the hot, early stage of the collision even heavy-quark bound states, like the Upsilon, are expected to melt in the collision. The group will study the melting pattern of Upsilons and their excited states with STAR and with CMS in pp, pA, and AA collisions. This measurement will provide crucial information to test models of the deconfinement of quarks in the high-temperature QGP. The second goal is to study the thermodynamic phase structure of the strong force. In particular, testing the existence of a predicted QCD critical point is a key component of this goal. This study is done with STAR by varying the collision energy both in collider and fixed-target collisions, and thereby exploring the transition between normal nuclear matter and QGP matter. Adding the fixed target energy scan is important because the current evidence suggests that the critical point may lie at the lowest energy accessible to the collider, and it is important to scan both above and below this transition. 

The broader impacts of this work are aimed at underrepresented minorities and women. The first is to communicate the excitement of high-energy nuclear physics to Latino students at the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS), through mentoring activities at the conference and support of the UC Davis SACNAS chapter. The second component is promotion of science and physics to elementary and high-school students through visits to elementary schools with large Latino populations, and via participation in the Adopt-A-Physicist program for high schools. Finally, the PIs in the project will mentor undergraduates, including NSF REU students, every year. A key part of these goals is the mentoring of graduate students to become leaders in these activities, since many are women and underrepresented minorities, and are therefore excellent role models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project uses very high energy collisions between nuclei to vaporize their neutrons and protons and to create microscopic and ephemeral droplets of quark-gluon plasma (QGP), which is understood to be the state of the universe one microsecond after the big-bang. The upsilon is a very heavy particle which is produced only when the QGP droplets are first formed. This project reports on the relative distributions of excited states of the upsilon using data from the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) detector at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Specifically, this project reports on the suppression of the 2S and 3S excited states. These excited state distributions can be used to determine the initial temperature of the QGP.

As the QGP droplets expand they also cool until they reach a phase boundary, at which point the quarks coalesce into a gas of mostly neutrons, protons, and pions. The nature of the phase transition between the QGP and the hot gas of particles can be explored by varying the energy of the collisions. This is done in the beam energy scan program at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC). Determining the nature and location of the phase boundary defines the phase diagram of matter operating under the strong nuclear force, also known as the Quantum Chromo-Dynamic (QDC) force. In order to fully understand the QCD phase diagram, it is necessary to go to energies low enough such that the initial temperature is too low to initiate QGP formation. A fixed-target program was developed at RHIC in order to achieve low enough energies. The beam energy scan program covers seven collider energies and twelve fixed-target energies. This project reports on studies of data from the Solenoidal Tracker at RHIC (STAR) detector at the lowest energy. Specifically, studies of the higher moments of the proton distribution for collisions at 3.0 GeV do not show evidence of critical fluctuations and the light charged particles spectra are consistent with emission from a hot hadronic gas. These studies confirm that QGP is not created at this low energy.

In order to bring these concepts to a general audience, one of the PIs of this project was the scientific advisor, narrator and lead on-screen talent for the IMAX movie "Secrets of the Universe". This movie focuses on the lives of physicists at the LHC and the science that they study. It is intended for IMAX and planetarium screens and is showing in science museums around the world. It is designed to spark interest in science. The target audience is teen-agers.

For the past several decades, NASA has been studying the effect of space radiation on spacecraft and on the astronauts and instruments that they carry. Most space radiation comes from either the solar wind or coronal mass ejections (solar flares), however high energy nuclei coming from distant supernovae make up a portion of the space radiation flux called "Galactic Cosmic Rays". RHIC is the only accelerator in the US that can provide the high energy nuclei present in the galactic cosmic rays and the STAR detector can make the measurements that NASA needs. One of the PIs of this project has demonstrated the capabilities to make the measurements and has developed a beam use request.
